error.signature: Jest: "global" coverage threshold for statements (80%) not met: 72.5%

verdict.summary: Code coverage fell below the configured threshold, causing the CI pipeline to fail. This is a quality gate check that ensures new code maintains minimum test coverage levels.

dead_ends.action: Lowering the coverage threshold to make CI pass
dead_ends.why_fails: This circumvents the quality gate entirely. Coverage will continue to drop over time without enforcement, accumulating untested code.

dead_ends.action: Adding trivial tests that increase coverage without testing meaningful behavior
dead_ends.why_fails: Tests that merely call functions without asserting behavior provide false coverage confidence. They pass coverage checks but do not catch bugs.

workarounds.action: Write meaningful tests for uncovered code paths
workarounds.how: Run coverage locally: npx jest --coverage. Review the coverage report to identify uncovered lines/branches. Write tests targeting the specific uncovered paths. Verify the threshold is met before pushing.

workarounds.action: Use per-file or per-directory thresholds instead of global
workarounds.how: Configure different thresholds for different parts of the codebase. In jest.config.js: coverageThreshold: { './src/critical/': { statements: 90 }, './src/utils/': { statements: 70 } }. This allows new code to have higher thresholds without penalizing legacy code.

leads_to.condition: when coverage failure also triggers SonarQube quality gate failure

preceded_by.condition: when flaky test timeouts cause some tests to be skipped, reducing coverage

frequently_confused_with.distinction: coverage-threshold-failed is enforced by the test runner (Jest, pytest, etc.); sonarqube-quality-gate is enforced by the SonarQube analysis platform which checks multiple quality metrics beyond coverage
